text: optimizing how your organization uses
its vehicle fleet is important for
logistic and service providers In this
video we will discuss about challenges
and demonstrate how to build and run a
solution for many to many vehicle
routing using Amazon location services
My name is Adil Ken I'm working as a
senior solution architect I will talk
about these challenges and Amazon
location service details and my
colleague Romesh Chidella will present
the architecture and follow up with a
demo
The fleet management market size has
grown rapidly in recent years It will
grow from 20 billion in 2024 and
expected 24 billion in 2025 with an
increase of
15% Optimizing how your organization
uses its vehicle fleet is important for
logistics and service
providers So what are the main
challenges high operational cost
Managing a fleet involves significant
expenses fuel maintenance insurance and
administrative cost Without effective
management these costs can escalate
reducing our
profitability Optimal route planning
leads to increased fuel consumption and
longer delivery date This inefficiency
not only raises cost but also impact
customer
satisfaction Without real-time
visibility it's challenging to monitor
vehicle locations and status This lack
of oversight can result in delays
mismanagement and reduced responsiveness
to unforeseen
events Handling such as scheduled bulk
and on demand requires flexibility
Coordinating different vehicles types
from trucks to bikes adds complexity to
these operations Our objective today is
to introduce a comprehensive cloud-based
solution designed to address these
challenges The goal is to optimize order
management reduce operational cost and
enhance overall fleet
efficiency By implementing this solution
we we can transform our fleet operations
making them more efficient more cost
effective and responsive to our our
needs So let's start and deep dive on
Amazon location
services What's Amazon location service
similar to everyday maps applications
that we are using but offered through
the AWS platform Amazon location
services is tailored to B2B use cases
powered by data from graph maps The
capabilities are customiz can visualize
data on map Recommend delivery routes
based on realtime traffic conditions
Convert plain text addresses into
geographical coordinates convert
customer and vehicle positions into
addresses and monitor the
track The slide highlights practical use
cases for the capabilities of Amazon
location
services The first one is visualize
location information on a map The map
capability to display geographical data
in your
application Such examples are show store
locations delivery rights or real-time
asset tracking on a map Second it offers
point of interest search functionality
Leverage the places feature for
geocoding and search Third it retrieve
current and historical location of
devices Fourth you will get travel time
distance and directions Use the rod
feature to calculate optimal path
between locations including estimated
travel time and distance And finally the
detect and act when a tracked device
enters or exits a boundary Employ the
geoences feature to set up alerts or
trigger actions when devices cross
predefined boundaries So how to start
using Amazon location services the first
step is select the data provider and
capabilities By choosing the data
provider and specific location based
features you need such as maps geocoding
routing and
joenses you will add the AWS SDK into
your application The SDK simplifies
integrating by providing pre-built tools
to interact with Amazon location
services If you are using another
location based service replace those API
calls in your code with equivalent calls
to Amazon location services
APIs By switching to Amazon location
services you can benefit from improved
data accuracy reduced cost and enhanced
user experience in your applications
Let's go through the solution
architecture The web interface built
with AWS Amplify gives dispatchers a
clear view of their delivery operations
Through Amazon location service they can
create optimized routes and track
vehicles on interactive maps AWS AppSync
ensures all information updates in real
time while AWS IoT Core processes the
continuous stream of location data from
vehicles Behind the scenes Amazon
Dynamob stores all delivery and route
information with AWS Lambda handling the
route
calculations The architecture can be
divided into three components Route
entry route calculation and route
tracking Route entry component leverages
amplify low code React development with
AWS appsync and Amazon Dynamob to enable
a field service dispatcher to enter and
store destination and waypoint locations
from a map
The route calculation component
leverages AWS Lambda location services
matrix routing and AppSync to
automatically create an optimized lowest
cost route based on the shortest time to
complete the trip and then displays the
optimized route on the map The route
tracking component integrates the
application with AWS AppSync AWS IoT
Core and location services tracker to
track our driver on the map as they
complete their route Let's see how this
works in practice using a real world
example We will walk through a scenario
for a delivery company operating in
Chicago's metropolitan area The
dispatcher is planning the deliveries
for the day starting from their
distribution center to various locations
Once you deploy this solution and run it
in your browser you will be presented
with the login screen You can create an
account using your email address and use
it to sign in After signing in you will
see the web-based dispatcher interface
We will now create an itinerary for
today's schedule by entering a name and
choosing a
date The create itinerary screen
displays an interactive map and enables
route entry The dispatcher can specify
route starting with the first
location As the dispatcher enters the
address amplifies location search
feature is used to display matching
addresses out of which the correct
destination address can be chosen After
entering all the addresses the
dispatcher is now ready to optimize the
routes The itineraries are optimized
using Amazon location route matrix API
This API returns a matrix with the
distance between each pairs of points of
the itinerary The matrix is then used to
optimize the route based on the shortest
distance between each pair of way points
After optimizing the routes the
dispatcher is now ready to start the
itinerary Once an itinerary starts an
asset outputed with an IoT sensor sends
position updates to AWS IoT core using
the message queuing telemetry transport
protocol For the purposes of this demo
the route tracking component simulates
an IoT sensor installed in the vehicle
AWS IoT Core routes the messages to a
location service tracker which stores
the position updates for up to 30 days
Users of the application can track the
assets on the map in near real time This
is achieved by pulling the updates from
the Amazon location tracker through an
AWS Lambda custom AWS AppSync
resolver This concludes our demo We have
seen how Amazon location services helps
organizations optimize their fleet and
delivery operations with route entry
route optimization and real-time
tracking The QR codes you see here point
to the solution guidance and sample code
on GitHub which can be used as a
starting point Thanks for your time and
have a great day
